photo.description: On the first day that my group spent together in India, Katie, Lisa, Adam, and I decided to go see the Lotus Temple. First we tried to take a couple bicycle rickshaws, which tried to drop us off at Lotus Tower—not quite the same, and certainly not worth the money we'd agreed to pay. So we took an auto rickshaw. Then we discovered that they'd just turned off all the lights. Waiting outside the gate, though, was a large group of Indian men, who said they were computer programmers. They seemed really excited to talk to me (I practiced my Hindi and they their English) but I found out later that my companions were terrified of being mugged or something. Anyway, we started walking up the street. I pulled out my tripod and was able to capture this view, and with a little magic, to remove the orange glow of the sodium streetlights.

photo.description: The Bahai House of Worship, better known as the Lotus Temple, in New Delhi, India. I do notice the tree obstructing the view, but I still like how the shot came out considering that I had barely a few seconds. I rested the camera on a small connection outlet of the local telephone company. The following info is courtesy of jlavezzo: Mashriqu'l-Adhkar is a formal title. It literally means "Dawning place of the mention of God". Bahá'u'lláh describes the Mashriqu'l-Adhkar as consisting of a temple, a hospital, schools, a place for travelers to stay, and a home for the elderly. The term designates the collection of buildings and services, but also correctly describes the temple itself, even before the other buildings are in place.
photo.tags: bahai house worship lotus temple delhi india lphometown night longexposure
photo.title: Bahá'í Mashriqu'l-Adhkar

photo.title: Visiting Sites in New Delhi

photo.tags: children lotustemple
photo.title: Visiting Sites in New Delhi

photo.description: Inspired by the lotus flower, the design for the House of Worship in New Delhi is composed of 27 free-standing marble clad "petals" arranged in clusters of three to form nine sides.[5] The nine doors of the Lotus Temple open onto a central hall slightly more than 40 meters tall[6] that is capable of holding up to 2,500 people. The surface of the House of Worship is made of white marble from Penteli mountain in Greece, the very same from which many ancient monuments and other Bahá'í Houses of Worship are built.[7] Along with its nine surrounding ponds and the gardens, the Lotus Temple property comprises 26 acres (105,000 m²; 10.5 ha).
photo.title: india (55) Lotus Temple -1987, the architect of the Bahá'í House of Worship, Mr. Fariborz Sahba, was presented the award for excellence in religious art and architecture by the UK-based Institution of Structural Engineers

photo.title: Lotus Temple

photo.description: The Lotus Temple or Bahai House of Worship, New Delhi, was designed by Mr. Fariborz Sahba, a Canadian Architect of Iranian Origin. This unique and charming building as the name indicates, designed like a lotus flower with three layers of nine petals. The RC structure is covered in pure white marble. There are nine Arched entrances and nine reflecting pools. From the airplane flying over it, this is an unforgettable sight, especially at sunrise and sunset. In my view, this is more beautiful than the Sydney Opera House. Those not lucky enough to enjoy this magnificent view from the air, a visit would do. More on this gem of a temple here www.pilgrimage-india.com/north-india-pilgrimage/bahai-tem...
photo.tags: lotus arches temple bahai delhi fariborzsahba white pretty operahouse sunset mywinners
photo.title: Sunset at Bahai Temple (Lotus Temple) Delhi

photo.description: The Temple features on most daily itineraries for (New) Delhi. I expected the 'temple' to belong to the Hindu faith, but it is in fact a 'Bahai House of Worship'. It's a very surrealistic scene as you arrive at the Temple. A constantly moving human chain moves, as through a sausage machine, into and out of the temple (virtually all are tourists). It felt like a scene that would have fitted right into the Hitchiker's Guide to the Galaxy. Visitors from all faiths are invited to spend time in meditation or prayer inside the temple, but it does ask for a kind of 'new age' orientation to faith, which I don't have. The architecture is quite something and I'd say a visit is worthwhile.
photo.tags: india goldentriangle delhi newdelhi
photo.title: The Lotus Temple in (New) Delhi

photo.description: God Grant that the light of unity may envelop the whole earth, and that the seal, "the kingdom is God's", may be stamped upon the brow of all its peoples. - Baha'u'llah. The Baha'i House of worship of the Indian sub-continent is the latest of the seven edifices raised in the different parts of the world, each with its distinctive design, each inviting people of different religions and races to worship the creator of the universe and to express the love between god and man. The design of the Baha'i' house of worship in New Delhi is inspired by the lotus, the exquisitely beautiful flower and symbol of purity that is inseparably associated with worship is surrounded by nine large pools of water that, not only enhance the beauty of the building but also play a significant role in the natural cooling system of the prayer hall. An adjunct of the main building is its ancillary building which houses offices, conference hall, library and audio-visual room.

photo.description: This puts me back a few years ago when I volunteered in Lotus Temple, New Delhi. It was fantastic experience! When I woke up in the morning, I looked forward to wear Sari. I've got 7 of them in different colours and motif. In the first day, I spent 2 hours to wrap around my body with the help of other volunteers. On some days, I wore Panjabi suits when I got tired of trying to put on Sari after spending 2.5 hours. And I got addicted after 2 weeks kept knocking on other volunteers' door to help me. I was proud that I can wear it on my own.
photo.tags: sari lotustemple bahaitemple
photo.title: Volunteering in New Delhi, 2002

photo.description: Located in the uphill village of Bahapur in the southern outskirts of New Delhi, the temple grounds were purchased in the 1950s from private fund donated by members of the Bahá'í Faith. The major part of this donation came from the entire life savings of Ardishir Rustampur of Hyderabad, India. Baharpur Hills, New Delhi, Delhi, India. 14 July 2007.

photo.description: The Bahá'í House of Worship opened to public worship in January 1987; since then, it has attracted more than 50 million visitors! Baharpur Hills, New Delhi, Delhi, India. 14 July 2007.
photo.tags: bahai bahaitemple houseofworship lotustemple temple delhi newdelhi india
photo.title: Baha'i Temple India

photo.description: As emphasized in the teachings of the Bahá'í Faith, the Bahá'í House of Worship be a gathering place for followers of all religions. Baharpur Hills, New Delhi, Delhi, India. 14 July 2007.
photo.tags: bahai bahaitemple houseofworship lotustemple temple delhi newdelhi india
photo.title: Baha'i Temple India

photo.description: Straight paths and walkways in the gardens and grounds provide a subtle contrast to the curves of the Bahá'í House of Worship, which has been designed with virtually no straight lines! Baharpur Hills, New Delhi, Delhi, India. 14 July 2007.
photo.tags: bahai bahaitemple houseofworship lotustemple temple delhi newdelhi india
photo.title: Baha'i Temple India

photo.description: In the future, the Bahá'í House of Worship will be surrounded by such facilities as schools, hospitals, homes for the aged, and other institutions in service to the community. This is stipulated in the Bahá'í sacred writings. Baharpur Hills, New Delhi, Delhi, India. 14 July 2007.
photo.tags: bahai bahaitemple houseofworship lotustemple temple delhi newdelhi india
photo.title: Baha'i Temple India

photo.description: Symmetrical in layout, the Bahá'í House of Worship encases a central hall within 27 free-standing marble "petals". These petals are grouped in three to form nine sides, and each side has a glass door that opens to the central hall. Baharpur Hills, New Delhi, Delhi, India. 14 July 2007.
photo.tags: bahai bahaitemple houseofworship lotustemple temple delhi newdelhi india
photo.title: Baha'i Temple India

photo.description: Rising from vast gardens and grounds, the Bahá'í House of Worship has attracted visitors from all religions and all walks of life. In a land of myriad diversities, the Baha'i House of Worship has become a symbol of the possibilities of unity in diversity. Baharpur Hills, New Delhi, Delhi, India. 14 July 2007.
photo.tags: bahai bahaitemple houseofworship lotustemple temple delhi newdelhi india
photo.title: Baha'i Temple India

photo.description: Brazenly ripping off the Sydney Opera House, as though it were a massive piece of steel origami, the Bahá'í built this still-mind-blowing house of worship in Delhi so that tourists like us would take photos like these and then look the place up on Wikipedia the next week to figure out what the hell we were actually looking at. - New Delhi, India
photo.title: The Lotus Temple

photo.description: ". . . the purpose of places of worship and edifices for adoration is simply that of unity, in order that various nations, divergent races, varying souls, may gather there and among them amity, love and accord may be realized." —From the Bahá'í sacred writings

photo.title: Symmetry in Architecture

photo.description: Diwali, the festival of lights, holds a special place in perhaps every Indian's heart. As my friends tried to describe it: start with the festivities of July 4th (or any other countries Independence day), add in the spirit of Christmas and mix it with the shopping mania of Thanksgiving (for the US) and you get what Diwali is all about. And being one of the few festivals that folks all over the country celebrate (yes, others do vary across the country), it seems to unite us in the spirit in a way nothing else can. And even when in a home away from home, we try to connect back to our culture in one way or another: lights adorn the homes of many Indian residents (even when against the fire code), visitations to the temples rise and lots of Indian sweets gets distributed. And this is how I celebrated it, in Google fashion. Some folks at Google organized a really event where lots of lamps get lit (and I mean lots). The above timelapse shows the lighting of the lamps. And the structure we recreated was the Lotus Temple in New Delhi, India Google Campus Mountain View CA USA
photo.tags: california google diwali timelapse sonydslra700 lights festival india
photo.title: Google Diwali Timelapse
